DATATYPE.Description: A very small integer. The signed range is -128 to 127. The unsigned range is 0 to 255.
A small integer. The signed range is -32768 to 32767. The unsigned range is 0 to 65535.
A medium-size integer. The signed range is -8388608 to 8388607. The unsigned range is 0 to 16777215.
A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.
A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.
A large integer. The signed range is -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807. The unsigned range is 0 to 18446744073709551615.
A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38.
A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38.

A normal-size (double-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -1.7976931348623157E+308 to -2.2250738585072014E-308, 0, and 2.2250738585072014E-308 to 1.7976931348623157E+308.
This is a synonym for DOUBLE.
This is a synonym for DOUBLE.
An unpacked floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Behaves like a CHAR column.
This is a synonym for DECIMAL.
A date. The supported range is \a1000-01-01\a to \a9999-12-31\a.
A date and time combination. The supported range is \a1000-01-01 00:00:00\a to \a9999-12-31 23:59:59\a.
A timestamp. The range is \a1970-01-01 00:00:00\a to sometime in the year 2037. The length can be 14 (or missing), 12, 10, 8, 6, 4, or 2 representing YYYYMMDDHHMMSS, ... , YYYYMMDD, ... , YY formats.
A time. The range is \a-838:59:59\a to \a838:59:59\a.
A year in 2- or 4-digit format (default is 4-digit).

A fixed-length string (1 to 255 characters) that is always right-padded with spaces to the specified length when stored. values are sorted and compared in case-insensitive fashion according to the default character set unless the BINARY keyword is given.
A variable-length string (1 to 255 characters). Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion unless the BINARY keyword is given.
This is a synonym for CHAR(1).
This is a synonym for CHAR(1).
A column maximum length of 255 (2^8 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 65535 (2^16 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 16777215 (2^24 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 4294967295 (2^32 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 255 (2^8 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 65535 (2^16 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 16777215 (2^24 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 4294967295 (2^32 - 1) characters.
An enumeration. A string object that can have only one value, chosen from the list of values.
A set. A string object that can have zero or more values, each of which must be chosen from the list of values.
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype

TABLE.Comments:
Defines relationship types. All types are assumed to be directional from \Achild\A to \Aparent\A, and are assumed to be transitive. This contradicts DAG-Edit which supports a wide variety of relationships including, cyclic, non-transitive, and non-directional relationships. The use of \Aparent\A and \Achild\A differs from GMOD which uses \Asubject\A and \Aobject\A in its relationships. In GMOD subject means child and object means parent. As long as we only have directional relationships, I favour parent and child because it is clearer.
 
Relationship names use the child to parent form of the relationship. 

There is no \Ais-a\A relationship in a mouse atlas database. The semantics of \Ais-a\A in the world of ontologies is that any property that a parent has is also held by the children. Thus, saying that a gene is expressed in a parent node of an is-a relationship, would imply that the gene is expressed in all the children. This would rarely be the case. However, is-a could have a place in terms of describing anatomy. Properties held by \Amuscle\A would also be help by \Aslow muscle\A, \Afast muscle\A, and \Asmooth muscle\A. It just doesn\at work for gene expression.

\Adevelops-from\A relationships are complicated in the mouse atlas. They have (at least) 3 related meanings:
\kol\g
 \kli\gSame path, same compenent, next stage: For example, \Abody/brain in stage x devolops into body/brain in stage x+1\A. This meaning is necessary because of Mouse Atlas\as use of timed nodes.\k/li\g
 \kli\gDiffernet path, same component, next stage: For example \Abody/brain in stage x devolops into body/head/brain in stage x+1\A. In this case, the component (brain) is the same, but the path to get to it has changed. This is necessary because of Mouse Atlas\as use of full paths to uniquely identify parts.\k/li\g
 \kli\gDifferent path, different component, next stage: For Example, \A.../metanephros/comma shaped nephron in stage x devolops into .../metanephros/s-shaped nephron in stage x+1\A. In this case the component changes.\k/li\g
\k/ol\g

I believe that the \ADifferent path, spawned component, same or next stage\A case, where only part of the original component develops into a different part (think mesenchyme) is a special case of the last item.

COLUMN.Comments: Name of relationship, such as \Apart-of\A \Adevelops-from\A, etc. Relationship names reflect the child to parent relationship.
Use when displaying the relationship from the child\as point of view, e.g., \Apart of\A, \Adevelops from\A
Use this when displaying the relationship from the parent\as point of view. e.g., \Ahas part\A, \Adevelops into\A

TABLE.Comments: Defines the standard staging series for a species. There is only one standard staging series per species and all alternative series are mapped to it. For mouse the one true staging series is Theiler. For Xenopus it is N\+F.\n

COLUMN.Comments: Persistent, unique, database wide ID for this stage.
Species the stage is defined for.
Name of the stage, e.g. TS01
Definitive ordering of this stage relative to all other stages for this species.
Alternatively, could have a URL here.

Very short additional text describing the stage. This is useful when real estate is tight but you still have enough space to give the user some additional information besides just the somtimes uninformative stage name. For mouse, this will likely be an equivalent DPC stage range. For Xenopus, this will likely be the short term for the stage, e.g., blastula.

TABLE.Comments:
This table implements the \Aabstract mouse\A. Defines every anatomy item in the organism.

Anatomy is actually a directed acyclic graph (DAG), meaning there can be multiple paths from any node in the graph back to the root. 

Primary and group nodes are defined as :
\kul\g\kli\gPrimary Component: These form the primary/canonical paths for navigating anatomy. They define a tree structure, where there is a unique path from the root to any component.\k/li\g\kli\gGroup Component: These were introduced to allow alternative ways to navigate anatomy. They effectively convert the anatomy tree to a DAG. Group compenents do not participate in canonical paths, except at the end of the path.\k/li\g\k/ul\g

It was decided at the 05/04/2006 Anatomy database meeting, that while canonical paths still exist they should be de-emphasised. See Mantis issue 101.

\kstrong\g:TODO:\k/strong\g This ignores a key case: nested groups.
\kstrong\g:TODO:\k/strong\g Validate that full_name is in fact the concatenation of the component names of this node and all its primary, part-of, ancestor nodes.

COLUMN.Comments: Persistent, unique, database wide ID for this anatomy node
Species this anatomy is for.
Name of this node. This is not unique.
True if this node is a primary node, false if it is a group node.
Published ID of htis node. For Mouse, this is an EMAPA ID. I presume that EMAPA was chosen so that we never accidentally display a node in the abstract mouse.

TABLE.Comments:
Contains a record for each individual stage that an anatomy node exists in. This table, more than any other table, defines what EMAP looks like to the outside world.

The GUDMAP and EuReGene projects use timed nodes to record annotation, but their query interface is much more driven by the abstract mouse defined in ANA_NODE.

COLUMN.Comments: Persistent, unique, database wide ID of this timed node
Untimed node this timed node is for.
Particualr stage at which this timed node exists.
Some timed nodes have stage modifiers, such as late or early. NULL for most records, meaning no modifier.
This is the public ID of this node. This, once generated, never changes. For EMAP, this takes the form \AEMAP:nnn\A

TABLE.Comments:
This table is \kstrong\gderived\k/strong\g from ana_node_relationship and ana_timed_node_relationship. It is used to quickly display anatomy for a stage in an indented tree format. This shows only part-of relationships. We display the anatomy as a tree, even though it is actually a DAG. Displaying a DAG is too darn difficult. 

There can be multiple records in this table for each corresponding record in ANA_NODE. There will be one record for each possible path to any node.

Until we have some way of coping with components under group nodes having the same component names, we can\at have a unique index on full path.

COLUMN.Comments: OID for this record. Since this table is derived, this does not persist across different generations of this table.
Start stage of the node this record is for. This has the same value in all records for this node.
End stage of the node this record is for. This has the same value in all records for this node.

Start stage of node as constrained by its place in the tree (that is, the start stages of its ancestor nodes along the current path.) This can be the same as or older than APO_NODE_START_STAGE_FK. This can have different values in different records for this node.

End stage of node as constrained by its place in the tree (that is, the end stages of its ancestor nodes along the current path.) This can be the same as or younger than APO_NODE_END_STAGE_FK. This can have different values in different records for this node.
Species this path exists in.
Anatomy node this part of path record is for.
Absolute ordering of how this anatomy node relative to all other anatomy nodes.
How deep in the tree the item is / how much to indent the item.

Full path from root to this anatomy node. There can be multiple paths from the root to any given node. Each path has its own record in this table. The path consists of an ordered list of components, with each component separated by a \A.\A
True if this is the primary path to this node; false if it is a secondary (via group) path.
Name that is most often displayed for the species, e.g. mouse, Xenopus laevis, etc.
Latin name of the species, e.g. mus musculus, Xenopus laevis, etc

TABLE.Comments: This table support synonyms for any anatomy object that has its ID in ANA_OBJECT.

COLUMN.Comments: Persistent, unique database wide ID of this synonym
Object this is a synonym for.

TABLE.Comments:
Defines binary, ordered relationships between objects in a mouse database. Well, only certain types of binary, ordered relationships.

Initially (04/2006), this table only contains relationships between nodes, and relationships between timed nodes. More broadly, in initially contains binary ordered relationships between objects of the same type.

We also thought about redefining timed nodes as a relationship between a node and a stage and then storing that relationship in this table. In that case, relationships between timed nodes would become relationships between relationships. While this has a certain elegance, if you take it to its extreme conclusion then you end up with a two table database: objects, and relationships. I don\at want to go there.

COLUMN.Comments: Persistent, unique, database wide ID for this relationship
Type of relationship
Parent in relatonship

TABLE.Comments:
This table is \kstrong\gderived\k/strong\g from ANA_RELATIONSHIP. It contains the transitive closure of all part-of relationships in that table. That is, for any nodes related in a child-parent, or grandchild-grandparent, or great-grandchild-great-grandparent, etc. relationships, there is an entry in this table. Transitivity does not cross relationship types. That is, the chain of relationships from ancestor to descdent will all be of the same type.

This table also stores \Aself-refrential\A records. For example \Abrain\A is a part of \Abrain\A. This greatly simplifies the SQL to check for expression in a part and all its descendents.

Eventually, it may also contain the transitive closure of lineage relationships as well.

COLUMN.Comments: OID of this record. Since this table is derived this OID is not persistent across different derivations of this table
Type of relationship that connects every link in the chain from ancestor to descendent.
Descendent in relationship
Ancestor in relationship

TABLE.Comments:
Sometimes a part appears particularly early or disappears particularly late in a stage. In such cases it is helpful to specify this in the anatomy.

We could further subdivide modifiers into those that can be applied to start stages, and those that can be applied to end stages. Might do this if it becomes a problem.

\kstrong\g:TODO:\k/strong\g Currently (03/2006) all stage modifiers are applied to either the first or last stage that a node exists at. Verify that stage modifiers exist only at start and stop stages.

COLUMN.Comments: Modifier name: \AAppears early\A, \AAppears late\A, \ALost early\A, \ALost late\A

TABLE.Comments: This table is a central place to store all persistent internal IDs. This table exists for two reasons:\n\kol\g\kli\gTo store attributes, such as creation time, that are common to all objects.\k/li\g\kli\gSo that we can have generic tables that still support foreign keys.\k/li\g\k/ol\g\n

COLUMN.Comments: ID value
Date and time when this ID and its corresponding record were created.

ID of editor who created this object. This is usually NULL, as we usually don\at know. This field should be an FK to ANA_EDITOR, but MySQL (or maybe just DBDesigner) does not support circular references.

TABLE.Comments: Stores version number of the database as a whole. Updates to the anatomy database are done infrequently, and when done, they are done as a coherent whole. This table records those updates. Each such update is a new version.\n

COLUMN.Comments: Unique, persistent database wide OID for this version.
Version number of the anatomy database as a whole. Assumes integer version numbers. This could easily be a string supporting sub-version numbers.
Datetime version was released.
Comments on this version.

TABLE.Comments: This implements record level (but not column level) attribution for any record type that stores its ID in ANA_OBJECT.

COLUMN.Comments: Persistent, unique, database wide ID of this attribution record.
Object this attribution is for.
Source for this attribution
Type of evidence that occurred in source, in support of this attribution.
Additional comments on this attribution. May be NULL, and usually is.

TABLE.Comments: Deescribes sources of information. These can be books, journal article, personal communication, ....

COLUMN.Comments: Persistent, unique, database-wide ID for this source.
Name of source. Could be book name, or Article name
List of authors in order and as they occur in the source.
Format the source is in.
Year source was created/published. We could store a full date here, but most of the time that is not appropriate.

TABLE.Comments:
This table records updates to the database. 

This version of the table is database centric. The assumption is that in the long run it will be populated by update and delete triggers on anatomy tables. In the short term, it will be populated by the same scripts that update the anatomy tables.

Since column names are unique in the database, storing just the column name is sufficient. but it is awkward. In order to find the table name the column is in, you need to strip off the 3 letter column name prefix, and then look that up in REF_ABBREVIATION. Not exactly graceful, but we can revisit when it becomes a priority.

This table does not store the new column value. Strictly speaking this is fine, since the new value is always available in the database table. However, the table would probably be easier to use if it stored both the old and new values.

The original design for this table stored the datetime that the change happened. The plan was to extract this from the CIOF file\as LastModificationTime fields. However, those are not reliable and are not even available for some object types. Therefore we switched to tagging records with the database version rather than the exact time of modification. Therefore any update that happened between versions will appear to have happened all at once, when the new version came out. With that change we also dropped the editor column from this table. The CIOF doesn\at tell us who made any particular change. Therefore, storing an editor in this table was fiction.

We should reconsider how we record time and responsibility if and when we start editing the anatomy in another format besides ObjectStore.

COLUMN.Comments: Unique, persistent ID for this log entry. This is not unique across the database.
OID of record that was updated. This could be a foreign key to ANA_OBJECT, but then we couldn\at keep history for deleted IDs.
Name of database column that was updated. Maximum 64 characters in a MySQL column name.
Old value of column expressed as a character string.
Comments on this update.

TABLE.Comments: Keeps a history of deleted public IDs so that we can direct queries that use them to what they have been replaced with. This table is meant to keep only a history of deleted PUBLIC IDs, not deleted internal IDs.

COLUMN.Comments: Public ID that has been deleted from the DB
Editor who deleted the ID
Reason the ID was deleted.
When the delete was done. This can be compared with the datetime on the version to determine which version this delete happened in.
Optional comments on why this was deleted.

TABLE.Comments: There are a limited number of reasons why a public ID can be deleted. This table defines those reasons.

COLUMN.Comments: Short text reason for delete. Can be diplayed. Examples are \Amerged\A, \Asplit\A, \Adeleted\A
Description of reason.

TABLE.Comments: Tables lists what public ID(s) replaced a deleted public ID. We keep track of this information so that we can redirect users who are using the old IDs.

COLUMN.Comments: (One of) the public ID(s) that replaced it, if it was replaced.
Public ID that was replaced.

TABLE.Comments: Defines editors in the database. Initially, the list of editors comes entirely from the lineage annotation in the CIOF file. There are only 3 editors to begin with.

COLUMN.Comments: Persistent, unique database wide ID of the editor.
Name of editor

TABLE.Comments: I thought about other names for the table: source_type, source_medium. Still looking for a better name.

COLUMN.Comments: Type of source, e.g. \Abook\A, \Ajournal article\A, \Apersonal communication\A

TABLE.Comments: This is a qualifier on the type of evidence that exists in a source. Initially, there is only one value.

COLUMN.Comments: Name of evidence type.

TABLE.Comments: Perspectives are particular views of subsets of the anatomy. Initially they are used to display only parts of the anatomy graph instead of the whole darn thing. \n\n

COLUMN.Comments: Name of perspective.
Description of perspective

TABLE.Comments: Defines what nodes participate in what perspectives.\n\nInitially, perspective membership lists are minimal. You pick the nodes from the anatomy you want to be in the perspective. All parent and child nodes of the selected nodes are then assumed to also be in the perspective. As long as this model works, the minimal membership lists will work well.

COLUMN.Comments: Unique ID of this row. This is not unique across the database.
Perspective the node is a part of.
Node that is a part of the perspective.

RELATION.Comments: Perspective the node is a part of.

NOTE.NoteText:
The design reflects conversations with Yiya, Duncan, Albert, Richard, Lorna and Jeff. It also incorporates elements from the eDIKT design, DAG-Edit, GMOD Chado, and ZFIN. See Mantis Issue 101 for more on this history of this design.

Known defficiences:
1. This design complely ignores images and spatial mapping. My belief is that these can be added later without significantly changing the foundation described here.
2. The deleted and logging tables are entirely untested. They are included here for discussion.

DERIVED TABLES:
There are 2 derived tables in this design. They exist to speed and simplify SQL:
 ANAD_PART_OF
 ANAD_RELATIONSHIP_TRANSTIVE
They are both tied to ANA_NODE.

ANATOMY:
Three core tables describe anatomy
ANA_STAGE: The single canonical staging series for a species.
ANA_NODE: Nodes in the anatomy graph. 
ANA_TIMED_NODE: Instances of ANA_NODE for each stage that the node exists in.
ANA_RELATIONSHIP: binary ordered relationships between nodes, and between timed nodes.
Proposed Anatomy table design for GMERG databases.\n
